image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: MDE-A, MDE-B and MDE-C Vertical Section Plot

formatted-caption.caption-text: MDE-A, MDE-B and MDE-C Vertical Section Plot

linkTarget.anchoringText: Where coiled tubing conveyance is concerned, the known disadvantage is the huge, heavy equipment footprint when compared to the smaller footprint of a wireline operation. Conventional coiled tubing equipment has an average weight of 13 Metric Tonnes (MT) but may reach to 20 metric tons (MT) depending on respective job requirements and well conditions. Below in Figure 3 showed the comparison of equipment layout on MDE platform between wireline and CT on the main-deck. As for this equipment footprint and weight, all options are viable with CPOC crane limitation of 13 MT except for E-Coil due to insufficient deck space of CPOC platform to accommodate its additional surface equipment requirement.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Platform Layout for CT (left) and Electric Line Unit (right).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Platform Layout for CT (left) and Electric Line Unit (right).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Typical rig ups for both coiled tubing and wireline tractor conveyance should be able accommodate the same gun length which is 10 ft section gun in a run. For longer gun length, additional surface equipment is typically necessary, such as an extended (telescopic) jacking frame for coiled tubing and 90ft telescopic mast in wireline tractor conveyance. This option also had been evaluated and resulted maximum of 20 ft section per run able to be deploying in a run. The surface rig up for both CT and wireline are illustrated in the Figure 4.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: CT Rig up Diagram (left) and Electric Line Rig up Diagram (right).

formatted-caption.caption-text: CT Rig up Diagram (left) and Electric Line Rig up Diagram (right).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Owing to the existence of multi-stacked reservoirs and the multiple thin impermeable and water-bearing zones (refer to FIGURE 5: MDE Wells Correlation), perforating the wells in this study requires a relatively accurate depth measurement system. By principle, conventional coiled tubing can provide a measurement of the pipe conveyed into the well but, in a similar fashion to the effect wire stretch has on wireline depth control; factors such as pressure, temperature, pipe deformation, helical buckling etc have quite significant effects on the accuracy of this measurement, varying considerably the actual pipe depth in the well.

All criteria were translated using the weighting factor and score for better indication on its priority and significant impact to this operation. This score weight or percentage was calculated based on all data computed for each option in the table. For instance, the lowest number of perforation runs will give the highest score that will then multiply by the weight factor. As per FIGURE 6 below, it showed that wireline downhole tractor with multi-stage pressure deployment system as the best feasible option.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Convenyance Options and Criteria Selection Comparison Study Summary

formatted-caption.caption-text: Convenyance Options and Criteria Selection Comparison Study Summary

linkTarget.anchoringText: Upon deployment (refer to Figure 7 – Deployment Method), the toolstring is divided into two deployment sections. The first deployment toolstring is the gun string with deployment bar connected to the cable head, the second deployment toolstring consists of the remaining toolstring such as correlation and tractor toolstrings. All arming procedures are adhered to prior to connecting the first deployment toolstring or gun assemblies.

On reverse deployment (refer to Figure 8 – Reverse Deployment Method), once the toolstring returns to surface, using the calculated distance from the tool catcher, the deployment bar will be located across the slip and pipe rams. The multistage pressure DBOP rams will be closed and any pressure in top section of PCE will be bled off. Next, an in-flow test will be performed to ensure the sealing integrity of the pipe rams. Then, the lubricator and second deployment toolstring will be disconnected. Following this, the cable head will be re-connected to the deployment bar for reverse deployment of the first deployment toolstring (gun string) by opening the rams, pulling out the tools to tool catcher and closing the X-Mas tree valves.

Total intervals of 269.5 meters were perforated as per initial plan. However, due to the request to perform more well tests, the perforation runs was changed and resulted total of 25 tractor perforation runs was made instead of 19 runs that has been originally planned. It also resulted in the change of the actual gun configuration. Figure 12 below showed the differences between original gun configuration and actual execution.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Comparison between Planned and Actual Gun Configurations

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison between Planned and Actual Gun Configurations

linkTarget.anchoringText: Based on the early evaluation made during the feasibility study, the actual job with additional runs showed slightly lower score than initially estimated but still higher in score as compared to CT conveyed perforation. Figure 13 showed the final score of actual operation as compared to all options that were evaluated during initial study.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Comparison between Plan and Actual Result

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison between Plan and Actual Result
